message:
Interesting fact: there is something called dev bootcamps that is becoming popular here in San Francisco, you join an extensive 9-week course that runs everyday from 9-to-5, you start from scratch, and by the end of the bootcamp you are ready to start working. It doesn't require any background, and they are proud that even baristas can join the program and get hired at tech after it.
All of that is indeed interesting, but the most interesting fact is that one of the three co-founders is EGYPTIAN :) He even studied in Egypt and then moved to SF.
story: Mohamed Osman shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Shereef Bishay on Bloomberg TV
caption: vimeo.com
description: Founded in February 2012 by software developer and social entrepreneur Shereef Bishay, Dev Bootcamp is a 9-week intensive training program that teaches adults to…

data.message: I know about bootcamps but I can't really wrap up my mind in how a person with no tech background can be fluent programmer and ready for work in weeks. That is why I think it raise the bar for every real geek to learn programming as a tool then move out to do more specific things like AI and machine learning since it will need real math and certain set of skills.

It's very similar to the ITI 9-Months program here :) , even it's more extensive in ITI, we're working officially from 8:30 to 3:30, and from 8:30 to 7:00 2 days a week, and  some days to 10:00 and 11:00 when they have projects.

We need to ask ourselves a question, how many courses we studied that we really used in our daily dev tasks. I would say 15%.
So bootcamps can prove many success stories in this field.
and then moved to SF. ..end of text

FYI - there's a coding bootcamp that is starting up in Egypt 
http://almakinah.com
